quoteFirst: May 1st, we remained in camp until
quoteLast: P.M., when we continued our march, and encamped about a mile beyond Hustonville. May 2d we advanced about ten miles in the afternoon, and encamped at Middleburgh, which is situated on a branch of the Green river.
title: History of the Thirty-sixth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers. 1862-1865

quoteFirst: The English were brave, and repulsed the attack throughout the day. At about
quoteLast: in the afternoon Joan was wounded by an arrow. She had prophesied this sometime before. The wound was not serious, however, and she went back into the battle.
title: The Mentor: Joan of Arc, v. 3, Num. 22, Serial No. 98, January 1, 1916
author: Tarbell, Ida M. (Ida Minerva), 1857-1944

quoteLast: in the afternoon, having a light breeze at N. E., and the tide of flood in our favour, we weighed and steered for the channel above mentioned, in hopes, after we were through, of finding the land trend away to the northward, or, at least, a passage out to sea to the W.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. VI. Being the Second of the Third Voyage

quoteLast: until eight or nine o'clock in the evening. Mr.

quoteFirst: He ordered me to make a ration return for that number of men, and send a sergeant to draw rations for thirty days' scout; and for me to hurry up, and when ready to report to Lieutenant Smith. By 12.45 my troop was ready and mounted, and reported as ordered, and
quoteLast: Troop's B and H pulled out from Fort Cumming for Lake Valley, New Mexico; and when the sun showed himself over the tops of the mountains we marched down the mountains into Lake Valley, thirty-five miles from Fort Cumming.
title: The Colored Regulars in the United States Army
author: Steward, T. G. (Theophilus Gould), 1843-1924

quoteFirst: A road climbing up from sloping fields turned abruptly and traversed the village, sidling up to the church; there, having apparently satisfied some itch of curiosity, it turned abruptly again and trundled back another way into that northern prospect of farms and forest that lay in the direction of Whitewater Copse, Hangman’s Corner, and
title: The Black Dog, and Other Stories
author: Coppard, A. E. (Alfred Edgar), 1878-1957
